Attempts light humor with Sir Nigel despite the cold reception, indicating some social attempt.
Strides confidently through the bullpen, acknowledged by other traders and interacts casually with them.
Offers a high five but leaves the other person hanging, showing some social awkwardness.
Denies responsibility for a large financial loss attributed to Kenny, possibly trying to avoid blame.
Requests to be brought up to date and immediately asks for relevant information and a double espresso, showing he intends to get back on track quickly.
Encounters Sir Nigel who ignores him initially, and Max does not assert himself in the power game, standing silently.
Follows orders promptly when Sir Nigel instructs him to sit.
Responds thoughtfully by questioning whether passions are truly virtues or vices, showing some insight.
Attempts to explain his actions to Sir Nigel and takes responsibility.
Does not respond when Gemma anxiously seeks information, instead silently handing her an unopened envelope and walking off.
Sits relaxed with feet on window sill while studying the enemy bank’s skyscraper, indicating strategic observation and confidence.
Turns red and is embarrassed in front of Fanny, barely able to respond in French, showing social awkwardness.
Considers partnership offer seriously and confidently responds with his choice, showing decisiveness and professional confidence.
Looks thoughtfully at the painting instead of immediately answering Sir Nigel, showing consideration.
Engages Fanny with a friendly and somewhat humorous remark about soup and his job.
Ignores Sir Nigel's direct question and remains focused on studying the painting instead of giving a clear decision.
Expresses clarity and confidence when telling Fanny he knows what he wants and does not need more time.
Listens calmly to the argument between Christie and Duflot without intervening, suggesting patience and tolerance.
Offers to 'soften up' the wine authorities for Christie, indicating willingness to help and be supportive.
Remains seated and somewhat detached during the conflict rather than stepping in to mediate or resolve tensions.
Watches attentively as Fanny and Madame Duflot tend to the lunch, appreciating the moment.
Responds to Charlie's skepticism with light humor and a smile, engaging warmly.
Accepts Fanny's affectionate gesture of tussling his hair and offers a smile.
Engages sociably with others at the lunch table after hanging up the phone.
Accurately recounts investment details and sets clear yield expectations, showing financial awareness and assertiveness.
Responds confidently to Charlie's doubts by taking a lighthearted but composed stance on his future success in the Provence estate, indicating measured self-confidence.
Passively receives wine and flirts with Fanny without taking active initiative, showing a relaxed but somewhat passive demeanor in social interactions.
